sect1.title: Sharing protocols
sect1.para: As with any storage array, there are two basic ways you can share the disk space: either as a character device or a block device. Given the DYI small storage array, characted device would be one of two popular network filesystem sharing protocols: NFS or CIFS, and block would be iSCSI protocol most probably. While you have freedom of chosing also an FC or FCoE protocols, I am not going to cover them here.

Original ZFS implementation allows for a quick sharing through NFS and CIFS protocols. The commands are tightly bound with ZFS itself and are represented at a filesytsem or a zvol property. Currently, at the moment this guide is written, the native ZFS share commands don't work with Linux platform. As with ACLs, you need to use Linux native tools, iscsiadm, samba, nfs server, to provide this functionality.

Please, be aware that describing complex NFS, Samba or iSCSI configurations warrant a separate book on its own for each of the protocols. Those are very out of the scope of this simple guide. There are number of books and a very large number of tutorials and HOWTOs for each of them available on the net, in case you need to work on something more complex.

sect1.title: NFS - Linux server
sect1.para: NFS is a flexible and proven network storage sharing protocol.

sect1.title: Other sharing protocols
sect1.para: You may want to share a ZFS zvol as an iscsi block device. Doing so on Linux platform is very easy.
